Definition: The ability to create, maintain, version, and communicate comprehensive AI policies that govern AI development, deployment, and operational activities
Key Components: Policy Authoring; Policy Repository; Version Control; Policy Communication; Policy Review Process; Policy Exception Management
Technologies: Policy management platforms (ServiceNow GRC, OneTrust); Document management systems; Workflow automation tools; Communication platforms (SharePoint, Confluence)
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc policies, manual distribution, limited version control
Maturity - Intermediate: Structured policies, centralized repository, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Automated policy management, stakeholder engagement, exception tracking
Maturity - Optimized: AI-assisted policy generation, continuous feedback, predictive policy updates
Success Metrics: Number of active AI policies; Policy compliance rate (%); Policy review cycle adherence (%); Average time to policy approval (days); Policy exception rate (%)

Definition: The capability to develop technical and operational standards that translate policies into actionable requirements for AI teams
Key Components: Technical Standards; Operational Guidelines; Architecture Standards; Security Standards; Data Standards; Integration Standards
Technologies: Standards management platforms; Architecture documentation tools (Draw.io, Lucidchart); Collaborative documentation platforms; Code quality and linting tools
Maturity - Basic: Inconsistent standards, limited documentation
Maturity - Intermediate: Documented standards, regular updates, basic enforcement
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive standards library, automated validation, 90%+ adoption
Maturity - Optimized: Self-evolving standards, continuous validation, 95%+ adoption
Success Metrics: Number of published standards; Standards adoption rate (%); Time to publish new standard (weeks); Standards compliance violations (#); Stakeholder satisfaction with standards (%)

Definition: The ability to integrate and align multiple governance frameworks (NIST AI RMF, ISO/IEC 42001, Basel Committee guidelines) into a cohesive governance approach
Key Components: Framework Mapping; Gap Analysis; Framework Harmonization; Compliance Mapping; Framework Updates; Certification Management
Technologies: GRC platforms with multi-framework support; Compliance management tools; Risk assessment platforms; Audit management systems
Maturity - Basic: Single framework, manual mapping, limited alignment
Maturity - Intermediate: Multiple frameworks, documented mappings, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Integrated frameworks, automated gap analysis, certification readiness
Maturity - Optimized: Continuous framework monitoring, proactive updates, multiple certifications
Success Metrics: Number of integrated frameworks; Framework alignment score (%); Gap remediation time (days); Certification audit findings (#); Framework update lag time (days)

Definition: The capability to establish and maintain organizational structures, roles, and responsibilities for AI governance oversight and execution
Key Components: Governance Board; AI Ethics Committee; Technical Review Committee; Risk Committee; Role Definitions; Decision Rights
Technologies: Organizational management tools; Workflow management systems; Committee collaboration platforms; Decision tracking systems
Maturity - Basic: Informal governance, unclear roles, ad-hoc meetings
Maturity - Intermediate: Defined committees, clear roles, regular meetings
Maturity - Advanced: Mature governance structure, cross-functional collaboration, efficient processes
Maturity - Optimized: Self-organizing governance, AI-assisted decision-making, continuous optimization
Success Metrics: Governance meeting attendance rate (%); Decision turnaround time (days); Governance escalation rate (%); Role clarity score (%); Cross-functional collaboration index

Definition: The ability to enforce governance policies, monitor compliance, and take corrective actions when violations occur
Key Components: Automated Policy Gates; Compliance Monitoring; Violation Detection; Remediation Workflows; Enforcement Actions; Compliance Reporting
Technologies: Policy enforcement engines; Continuous compliance monitoring tools; Automated testing frameworks; Workflow automation platforms; Reporting and analytics tools
Maturity - Basic: Manual enforcement, reactive monitoring, limited visibility
Maturity - Intermediate: Automated gates, regular monitoring, documented violations
Maturity - Advanced: Real-time monitoring, proactive enforcement, automated remediation
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive enforcement, self-healing systems, zero-trust architecture
Success Metrics: Policy violation rate (%); Violation detection time (hours); Remediation completion rate (%); Average remediation time (days); Repeat violation rate (%)

Definition: The ability to identify, classify, and assess risks associated with AI systems throughout their lifecycle
Key Components: Risk Taxonomy; Risk Assessment Methodology; Risk Scoring; Risk Appetite Definition; Impact Analysis; Risk Register
Technologies: Risk assessment platforms; Risk scoring algorithms; Impact analysis tools; Risk visualization dashboards; Risk register databases
Maturity - Basic: Manual risk assessment, inconsistent methodology, limited tracking
Maturity - Intermediate: Structured risk assessment, documented methodology, risk register
Maturity - Advanced: Automated risk scoring, continuous assessment, predictive analytics
Maturity - Optimized: AI-powered risk prediction, real-time assessment, proactive mitigation
Success Metrics: Number of risks identified and assessed; Risk assessment coverage (% of AI systems); Average risk assessment time (hours); Risk prediction accuracy (%); Unidentified risk incidents (#)

Definition: The capability to manage risks specific to AI/ML models following banking regulatory guidelines (Basel Committee SR 11-7)
Key Components: Model Inventory; Model Risk Classification; Model Validation; Backtesting & Stress Testing; Challenger Models; Model Limitations; Ongoing Monitoring
Technologies: Model risk management platforms; Model validation tools; Statistical testing frameworks; Backtesting engines; Model monitoring systems
Maturity - Basic: Manual model tracking, limited validation, reactive monitoring
Maturity - Intermediate: Model inventory, structured validation, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Automated validation, continuous monitoring, challenger models
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive risk assessment, self-validating models, real-time adaptation
Success Metrics: Model inventory completeness (%); Validation coverage rate (%); Model validation cycle time (weeks); Validation findings per model (#); Model performance drift incidents (#)

Definition: The ability to ensure AI systems comply with banking regulations, financial services requirements, and data protection laws
Key Components: Regulatory Mapping; Compliance Controls; Regulatory Reporting; Compliance Testing; Regulatory Change Management; Evidence Collection
Technologies: Regulatory compliance platforms; Automated reporting tools; Control testing frameworks; Regulatory intelligence systems; Evidence management systems
Maturity - Basic: Manual compliance tracking, reactive approach, limited documentation
Maturity - Intermediate: Compliance framework, regular testing, documented controls
Maturity - Advanced: Automated compliance monitoring, proactive testing, comprehensive evidence
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive compliance, real-time monitoring, continuous attestation
Success Metrics: Regulatory compliance rate (%); Compliance test failure rate (%); Regulatory report submission timeliness (%); Regulatory findings per audit (#); Time to implement regulatory changes (days)

Definition: The capability to provide independent assurance through internal and external audits, maintaining comprehensive audit trails and evidence
Key Components: Audit Trail Management; Evidence Collection; Internal Audit Support; External Audit Support; Attestation Processes; Audit Remediation
Technologies: Audit trail logging systems; Evidence management platforms; Audit workflow management; Attestation tracking systems; Remediation management tools
Maturity - Basic: Manual logging, scattered evidence, reactive audit support
Maturity - Intermediate: Centralized logging, organized evidence, audit readiness
Maturity - Advanced: Automated evidence collection, continuous audit readiness, proactive remediation
Maturity - Optimized: Real-time audit trail, self-service audit evidence, predictive remediation
Success Metrics: Audit trail completeness (%); Average audit preparation time (days); Audit findings per review (#); Finding remediation time (days); Repeat audit findings (#)

Definition: The ability to assess, monitor, and manage risks associated with third-party AI vendors, models, and services, with specific attention to concentration risks
Key Components: Vendor Assessment; Contract Management; Vendor Monitoring; Third-Party Model Validation; Exit Strategy; Concentration Risk Management; AI Systemic Risk Assessment; Model Provider Concentration; Critical Service Provider Oversight
Technologies: Third-party risk management platforms; Vendor assessment tools; Contract lifecycle management systems; Vendor monitoring dashboards; Due diligence automation tools
Maturity - Basic: Manual vendor assessment, limited monitoring, reactive management
Maturity - Intermediate: Structured assessment, regular reviews, documented risks
Maturity - Advanced: Automated monitoring, comprehensive due diligence, proactive management
Maturity - Optimized: Continuous vendor assessment, predictive risk scoring, dynamic risk management
Success Metrics: Vendor assessment coverage (%); Vendor assessment cycle time (weeks); Vendor compliance rate (%); Vendor-related incidents (#); Average vendor risk score

Definition: The capability to systematically identify assess and mitigate security threats specific to AI/ML systems using industry-standard threat modeling frameworks
Key Components: Threat Modeling Frameworks; Adversarial Attack Assessment; AI-Specific Vulnerability Scanning; Security Testing; Threat Intelligence; Security Architecture Review; Red Team Exercises
Technologies: MITRE ATLAS framework; OWASP LLM Top 10 guidelines; AI security testing tools (Adversarial Robustness Toolbox); Threat modeling platforms; AI red teaming frameworks
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc security assessments, limited AI-specific testing
Maturity - Intermediate: Regular threat modeling, OWASP LLM Top 10 coverage
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive threat modeling (STRIDE + MITRE ATLAS), automated testing
Maturity - Optimized: Continuous threat modeling, AI-powered threat detection, proactive defense
Success Metrics: Threat modeling coverage (% of AI systems); AI vulnerabilities identified (#); Mean time to patch AI vulnerabilities (days); Red team exercise frequency (#/year); AI security incidents prevented (#)

Definition: The capability to detect, respond to, and learn from AI-related incidents including failures, security breaches, and compliance violations
Key Components: Incident Detection; Incident Classification; Response Procedures; Escalation Management; Root Cause Analysis; Post-Incident Review; Incident Reporting
Technologies: Incident management systems; Automated alerting platforms; Incident response orchestration; Root cause analysis tools; Reporting and analytics platforms
Maturity - Basic: Reactive incident response, manual processes, limited documentation
Maturity - Intermediate: Defined procedures, incident tracking, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Automated detection, orchestrated response, comprehensive analysis
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive incident prevention, self-healing systems, continuous learning
Success Metrics: Incident detection time (minutes); Mean time to respond (MTTR) (hours); Mean time to resolve (hours); Incident recurrence rate (%); Lessons learned implementation rate (%)

Definition: The ability to establish, implement, and maintain comprehensive ethical frameworks that guide AI development and decision-making
Key Components: Ethical Principles; Ethics Review Process; Ethical Impact Assessment; Stakeholder Engagement; Ethics Training; Ethics Committee
Technologies: Ethics assessment frameworks; Stakeholder engagement platforms; Ethics training modules; Decision support systems; Ethics documentation tools
Maturity - Basic: Informal ethical guidelines, ad-hoc reviews, limited awareness
Maturity - Intermediate: Documented principles, structured reviews, basic training
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive framework, systematic assessments, broad awareness
Maturity - Optimized: Embedded ethics, proactive assessments, cultural integration
Success Metrics: Ethical review coverage (% of AI projects); Ethics training completion rate (%); Ethical issues identified (#); Stakeholder engagement score; Ethics-driven design changes (#)

Definition: The capability to identify, measure, and mitigate biases in AI systems that could lead to unfair or discriminatory outcomes
Key Components: Bias Testing; Fairness Metrics; Bias Monitoring; Mitigation Strategies; Dataset Diversity; Bias Reporting
Technologies: Bias detection tools (AI Fairness 360, Fairlearn); Fairness metrics libraries; Data profiling tools; Synthetic data generation; Bias monitoring dashboards
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc bias testing, manual analysis, reactive mitigation
Maturity - Intermediate: Regular bias testing, documented metrics, proactive mitigation
Maturity - Advanced: Automated bias detection, continuous monitoring, systematic mitigation
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive bias detection, self-correcting systems, zero-tolerance culture
Success Metrics: Bias testing coverage (% of models); Bias detection rate (%); Bias mitigation effectiveness (%); Disparate impact ratio; Bias-related incidents (#)

Definition: The ability to assess and ensure fair treatment and outcomes across different demographic groups and customer segments
Key Components: Fairness Criteria Definition; Fairness Testing; Demographic Analysis; Disparate Impact Testing; Fair Lending Compliance; Continuous Monitoring
Technologies: Fairness testing frameworks; Statistical analysis tools; Demographic data platforms; Fair lending compliance tools; Fairness monitoring dashboards
Maturity - Basic: Limited fairness testing, manual analysis, reactive approach
Maturity - Intermediate: Regular fairness testing, documented criteria, proactive monitoring
Maturity - Advanced: Automated fairness testing, comprehensive analysis, systematic remediation
Maturity - Optimized: Real-time fairness monitoring, self-adjusting systems, continuous improvement
Success Metrics: Fairness test coverage (% of models); Fairness violation rate (%); Disparate impact ratio; Fair lending compliance rate (%); Fairness-related complaints (#)

Definition: The capability to make AI systems understandable, interpretable, and explainable to stakeholders including customers, regulators, and employees
Key Components: Model Interpretability; Explanation Generation; Decision Traceability; User Communication; Regulatory Explanations; Explainability Standards
Technologies: Explainability frameworks (LIME, SHAP, Integrated Gradients); Model interpretation tools; Decision tracking systems; Natural language generation for explanations; Visualization tools
Maturity - Basic: Limited explainability, black-box models, manual explanations
Maturity - Intermediate: Basic interpretability tools, documented decision logic, structured explanations
Maturity - Advanced: Automated explanations, multi-level interpretability, comprehensive traceability
Maturity - Optimized: Real-time explanations, adaptive explanation depth, stakeholder-specific explanations
Success Metrics: Explainability coverage (% of models); Explanation quality score; Time to generate explanation (seconds); Stakeholder satisfaction with explanations (%); Right to explanation requests (#)

Definition: The capability to protect customer privacy and ensure data protection throughout the AI lifecycle in compliance with privacy regulations
Key Components: Privacy Impact Assessment; Data Minimization; Consent Management; Anonymization & Pseudonymization; Data Subject Rights; Privacy-Preserving AI
Technologies: Privacy impact assessment tools; Data anonymization tools; Consent management platforms; Privacy-preserving ML frameworks; Data subject rights automation
Maturity - Basic: Manual privacy assessments, limited anonymization, reactive approach
Maturity - Intermediate: Structured assessments, basic anonymization, documented processes
Maturity - Advanced: Automated privacy testing, advanced anonymization, privacy by design
Maturity - Optimized: Privacy-preserving AI, zero-knowledge proofs, continuous privacy monitoring
Success Metrics: Privacy impact assessment coverage (%); Data minimization score (%); Consent compliance rate (%); Data subject rights response time (days); Privacy violations (#)

Definition: The capability to maintain a comprehensive, centralized catalog of all AI/ML models with complete metadata, versioning, and lineage information
Key Components: Centralized Repository; Metadata Management; Version Control; Lineage Tracking; Model Discovery; Model Classification
Technologies: Model registry platforms (MLflow, AWS SageMaker Model Registry); Metadata management systems; Lineage tracking tools; Version control systems; Search and discovery engines
Maturity - Basic: Spreadsheet-based tracking, limited metadata, manual updates
Maturity - Intermediate: Centralized registry, structured metadata, automated registration
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive registry, full lineage, advanced search, API access
Maturity - Optimized: Self-registering models, AI-powered discovery, predictive metadata
Success Metrics: Model registry completeness (%); Metadata completeness score (%); Model discovery time (minutes); Unregistered models in production (#); Lineage accuracy (%)

Definition: The capability to implement structured approval processes and independent validation for AI models before production deployment
Key Components: Approval Workflows; Stakeholder Review; Independent Validation; Technical Validation; Business Validation; Compliance Validation; Approval Documentation
Technologies: Workflow management systems; Model validation frameworks; Testing automation tools; Approval tracking systems; Documentation management platforms
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc approvals, limited validation, manual processes
Maturity - Intermediate: Defined workflows, structured validation, documented approvals
Maturity - Advanced: Automated gates, comprehensive validation, independent review
Maturity - Optimized: AI-assisted validation, dynamic approval paths, continuous validation
Success Metrics: Approval cycle time (days); Approval rejection rate (%); Validation finding severity (#); Approval documentation completeness (%); Production defect rate (%)

Definition: The capability to maintain comprehensive documentation of models and track their complete lineage from data sources through deployment
Key Components: Model Cards; Technical Documentation; Data Lineage; Development History; Dependency Mapping; Change History; Usage Documentation
Technologies: Model card generation tools; Documentation automation platforms; Lineage tracking systems; Dependency graph tools; Version control systems
Maturity - Basic: Manual documentation, incomplete lineage, scattered information
Maturity - Intermediate: Structured documentation, basic lineage, centralized storage
Maturity - Advanced: Automated documentation, comprehensive lineage, integrated systems
Maturity - Optimized: Self-documenting models, real-time lineage, AI-generated documentation
Success Metrics: Documentation completeness score (%); Lineage coverage (%); Documentation update lag (days); Documentation access time (minutes); Audit finding rate on documentation (%)

Definition: The capability to continuously monitor model performance in production, detecting degradation, drift, and anomalies in real-time
Key Components: Performance Metrics Tracking; Data Drift Detection; Concept Drift Detection; Anomaly Detection; Alerting & Notification; Performance Dashboards; Automated Remediation
Technologies: Model monitoring platforms (Evidently AI, WhyLabs, Arize); Data drift detection tools; Real-time alerting systems; Performance dashboards; Automated remediation frameworks
Maturity - Basic: Manual monitoring, periodic reviews, reactive approach
Maturity - Intermediate: Automated metrics collection, basic alerting, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Real-time monitoring, comprehensive drift detection, proactive alerts
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive monitoring, self-healing models, automated retraining
Success Metrics: Monitoring coverage (% of production models); Drift detection accuracy (%); Alert response time (minutes); False positive alert rate (%); Model performance incidents (#)

Definition: The capability to manage model versions, control changes, and ensure safe updates to production models
Key Components: Version Control; Change Request Management; Impact Assessment; Deployment Strategies; Rollback Capability; Change Documentation; Approval Gates
Technologies: Version control systems (Git, DVC); Change management platforms; Deployment automation tools; Feature flags and experimentation platforms; Rollback automation
Maturity - Basic: Manual versioning, uncontrolled changes, risky deployments
Maturity - Intermediate: Automated versioning, change requests, basic deployment strategies
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive version control, controlled deployments, quick rollback
Maturity - Optimized: Automated change management, zero-downtime deployments, instant rollback
Success Metrics: Change request approval time (days); Deployment success rate (%); Rollback frequency (#); Change-related incidents (#); Deployment lead time (hours)

Definition: The capability to safely retire and decommission models that are no longer needed, performing poorly, or have been superseded
Key Components: Retirement Criteria; Retirement Planning; Dependency Analysis; Data Archival; Documentation Update; Communication; Audit Trail
Technologies: Lifecycle management platforms; Dependency analysis tools; Archival systems; Notification systems; Audit logging systems
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc retirement, manual processes, incomplete documentation
Maturity - Intermediate: Defined criteria, planned retirement, basic archival
Maturity - Advanced: Automated retirement triggers, comprehensive archival, stakeholder notification
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive retirement, automated decommissioning, complete lifecycle management
Success Metrics: Retirement planning lead time (weeks); Successful retirements without incidents (%); Documentation completeness at retirement (%); Orphaned models in production (#); Archival completeness (%)

Definition: The ability to provide real-time visibility into governance metrics compliance status and risk posture through comprehensive dashboards and reports
Key Components: Executive Dashboards; Operational Dashboards; Compliance Dashboards; Risk Dashboards; Custom Reports; Automated Reporting; Drill-Down Capability
Technologies: Business intelligence platforms (Tableau, Power BI, Looker); Data visualization tools; Report automation platforms; Data warehouse and analytics; Dashboard development frameworks
Maturity - Basic: Manual reporting, static reports, limited visualization
Maturity - Intermediate: Semi-automated reports, basic dashboards, regular updates
Maturity - Advanced: Real-time dashboards, interactive visualizations, automated distribution
Maturity - Optimized: AI-powered insights, predictive analytics, self-service analytics
Success Metrics: Dashboard availability (uptime %); Report generation time (hours); Data freshness (lag time); Dashboard user adoption (%); Stakeholder satisfaction with reporting (%)

Definition: The capability to continuously monitor AI systems, governance controls, and compliance status with real-time alerting for issues
Key Components: Real-Time Monitoring; Automated Alert Rules; Alert Prioritization; Alert Routing; Alert Response Tracking; Alert Analytics; False Positive Management
Technologies: Continuous monitoring platforms; Alerting and notification systems; Log aggregation and analysis; Anomaly detection systems; Alert management platforms
Maturity - Basic: Manual monitoring, reactive alerts, limited coverage
Maturity - Intermediate: Automated monitoring, basic alerting, regular reviews
Maturity - Advanced: Real-time monitoring, intelligent alerting, comprehensive coverage
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive monitoring, AI-powered alerting, self-healing systems
Success Metrics: Monitoring coverage (%); Alert response time (minutes); False positive rate (%); Alert resolution time (hours); Undetected incidents (#)

Definition: The capability to regularly test and validate compliance controls, policies, and procedures to ensure they are operating effectively
Key Components: Control Testing; Policy Validation; Automated Testing; Test Case Management; Test Evidence Collection; Finding Management; Continuous Testing
Technologies: Compliance testing frameworks; Automated testing tools; Test management platforms; Evidence collection systems; Finding tracking systems
Maturity - Basic: Manual testing, periodic reviews, limited coverage
Maturity - Intermediate: Regular testing, documented test plans, basic automation
Maturity - Advanced: Automated testing, continuous testing, comprehensive coverage
Maturity - Optimized: Continuous validation, self-testing systems, predictive testing
Success Metrics: Testing coverage (% of controls); Test frequency (tests per month); Control failure rate (%); Finding remediation time (days); Repeat findings (#)

Definition: The capability to define, collect, analyze, and report on key performance indicators (KPIs) and metrics that measure governance effectiveness
Key Components: KPI Framework; Metrics Definition; Data Collection; Benchmarking; Trend Analysis; Target Setting; Performance Reporting
Technologies: KPI management platforms; Data collection and aggregation tools; Analytics and reporting platforms; Benchmarking databases; Target tracking systems
Maturity - Basic: Limited metrics, manual collection, inconsistent reporting
Maturity - Intermediate: Defined KPIs, semi-automated collection, regular reporting
Maturity - Advanced: Comprehensive KPIs, automated collection, trend analysis
Maturity - Optimized: Predictive KPIs, real-time metrics, AI-powered insights
Success Metrics: KPI coverage (% of governance areas); Data quality score (%); Reporting timeliness (%); KPI target achievement rate (%); Stakeholder use of metrics (%)

Definition: The capability to systematically assess governance maturity, identify improvement opportunities, and implement continuous improvement initiatives
Key Components: Maturity Assessment; Gap Analysis; Improvement Planning; Best Practice Integration; Lessons Learned; Process Optimization; Change Management
Technologies: Maturity assessment frameworks; Gap analysis tools; Project management platforms; Best practice repositories; Change management systems
Maturity - Basic: Ad-hoc assessments, limited improvement focus, reactive changes
Maturity - Intermediate: Regular assessments, documented improvements, planned changes
Maturity - Advanced: Continuous assessment, systematic improvement, proactive optimization
Maturity - Optimized: Self-assessment, AI-driven improvement, continuous evolution
Success Metrics: Maturity score improvement (annual); Improvement initiative completion rate (%); Time to implement improvements (weeks); Stakeholder feedback on improvements (%); Return on governance investment (%)
